{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1971 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 1 | APRank = 1 | Record = 13-0-0 | ConfRecord = 7-0-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Bob Devaney]] | HCYear = 10th | OffCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | OCYear = 3rd | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Big 8 Champions
Orange Bowl Champions
Consensus National Champions | BowlTourney = [[1972 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] vs. #2 [[1971 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] | BowlTourneyResult = W 38-6 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1971 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1971 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1971 college football season]]. Nebraska was coached by [[Bob Devaney]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. The Huskers were undefeated at 13-0, repeating as [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national champions]]. ==Schedule== The 1971 Cornhuskers were one of the most dominant teams in college football history, winning twelve of their thirteen games by 24 points (or more) and defeating the next three teams in the final AP poll. The sole close game of the season was the [[Game of the Century (college football)#1971 Nebraska vs. Oklahoma|Game of the Century]] at #2 [[1971 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] on [[Thanksgiving Day|Thanksgiving]]. Nebraska decisively beat #3 [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]] (then #9) 31-7 in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Lincoln]] and #4 [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama]] (then #2) 38-6 in the [[1972 Orange Bowl]] in [[Miami Orange Bowl|Miami]]. {{Cite web |url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1971 |title =Football - 1971 Schedule/Results NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''[[Warren Powers]]'''|||Defensive Backs||align="center"| ||align="center"|1969-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Boyd Epley'''|||Head Strength Coach||align="center"|1969||align="center"|1969-2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Bill Thornton'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1970-71||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''[[Jim Walden]]'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1971-72||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |} ==Game notes== ===Oregon=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oregon at #2 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=University of Oregon|team=Oregon Ducks|title=Oregon}} | Host = '''#2 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 7| H4 = 13 | Date = 1971-09-11 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,437 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} The Nebraska reserves were on the field in the 4th quarter, working under a comfortable 34-0 lead, when a fumbled punt allowed Oregon to put in a late score to avoid the shutout with 3 minutes to play. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Minnesota at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1971 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 14| H4 = 0 | Date = 1971-09-18 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 68,187 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Minnesota managed a 2nd quarter touchdown, but the game was never really in doubt as Nebraska extended their unbeaten streak to 21 games. {{-}} ===Texas A&M=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Texas A&M at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=Texas A&M University|team=Texas A&M Aggies|title=Texas A&M}} | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 7| H2 = 6| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1971-09-25 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,993 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Two huge plays left Nebraska's signature on the Texas A&M win, as [[Johnny Rogers]] tore off a 98-yard kickoff return for a touchdown, and Bill Kosch returned an interception 95 yards for a score of his own. The Aggies also managed a big score for their only points, an equally-impressive 94 yard kickoff return touchdown. {{-}} ===Utah State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Utah State at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=Utah State University|team=Utah State Aggies|title=Utah State}} | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 6| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1971-10-02 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,421 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Utah State was behind 0-35 when they managed to avoid the shutout with a 3rd quarter touchdown, but the PAT was blocked. The Cornhuskers ran the margin of victory back up again with a final fourth quarter touchdown. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at Missouri''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#1 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | V1 = 0| V2 = 16| V3 = 14| V4 = 6 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1971-10-09 | Location = [[Faurot Field]], [[Columbia, Missouri]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 61,200 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Nebraska was held scoreless for over 20 minutes, but Missouri eventually succumbed to the pressure as Nebraska then ran up 36 points and shut out the Tigers in Columbia. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Kansas at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 14| H3 = 13| H4 = 14 | Date = 1971-10-16 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 68,331 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Nebraska smashed Kansas at Homecoming for another shutout, holding the Jayhawks to 56 yards of total offense, barely more than one tenth of the Cornhuskers' 538 yards. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at Oklahoma State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#1 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 14| V3 = 13| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 13 | Date = 1971-10-23 | Location = [[Boone Pickens Stadium|Lewis Field]], [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 37,000 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} All of Oklahoma State's entire scoring was picked up in the last 2 minutes against Nebraska reserves, making the game appear closer than it was, if 41-13 can be called close. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Colorado at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #9 [[1971 Colorado Buffaloes football team|Colorado]] | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 17| H3 = 7| H4 = 0 | Date = 1971-10-30 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,776 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Nebraska rolled right out to a 24-0 lead by halftime and was cruising against #9 Colorado without much effort. The Buffaloes did manage a 3rd quarter touchdown on a broken play, but Nebraska matched it and easily held on for the win. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Iowa State at #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 10| H2 = 10| H3 = 7| H4 = 10 | Date = 1971-11-06 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,201 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} The Cornhuskers held Iowa State to just 105 yards of offense and had no trouble holding the Cyclones off the scoreboard for another shutout on the season. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at Kansas State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#1 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1971 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | V1 = 14| V2 = 16| V3 = 7| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 9| H3 = 0| H4 = 8 | Date = 1971-11-13 | Location = [[Bill Snyder Family Football Stadium|KSU Stadium]], [[Manhattan, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 42,300 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Nebraska QB [[Jerry Tagge]] became the first Cornhusker to exceed 5000 career yards at Kansas State as Nebraska scored touchdowns on each of its first four possessions. [[Johnny Rodgers]] also entered the record book with his 10 season touchdown receptions, 45 receptions on the season, and 84 receptions for his career. No other team managed to score so many points on Nebraska this season as did the Wildcats, but another convincing win was behind them as Nebraska prepared for a showdown with #2 Oklahoma to decide the Big 8 title and potentially the national championship. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at #2 Oklahoma''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#1 Nebraska''' | Host = #2 [[1971 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] | V1 = 7| V2 = 7| V3 = 14| V4 = 7 | H1 = 3| H2 = 14| H3 = 7| H4 = 7 | Date = 1971-11-25 | Location = [[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium|Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]], [[Norman, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = 1:30 pm | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 61,826 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} [[1971 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] and Nebraska battled back and forth in the [[Game of the Century (college football)#1971 Nebraska vs. Oklahoma|Game of the Century]] in front of a sold-out crowd in [[Norman, Oklahoma|Norman]] and over 55 million viewers on ABC-TV on [[Thanksgiving Day]]. Nebraska struck first with a 72-yard [[Johnny Rodgers]] punt return, but Oklahoma pulled ahead by 3 by halftime. The Cornhuskers came back strong in the third quarter with two more touchdowns, but the Sooners responded with two of their own to retake the lead with only 7:10 remaining. Down by 3 points, the Huskers went on a final drive and with only 1:38 remaining, [[Jeff Kinney]] scored his fourth touchdown of the day for the lead and the win. {{-}} ===Hawaii=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at Hawaii''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#1 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1971|school=University of Hawaii at Manoa|team=Hawaii Rainbows|title=Hawaii}} | V1 = 17| V2 = 7| V3 = 7| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 3| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1971-12-04 | Location = [[Honolulu Stadium]], [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|Honolulu, Hawaii]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 23,002 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} Almost 1/3 of the fans in the relatively sparse crowd were dressed in red and rooting for the Cornhuskers as Nebraska handily won this game almost as an afterthought to the vacation in Honolulu. It was 24-3 at the half, and Hawaii never saw the scoreboard again. {{-}} ===Alabama=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#2 Alabama vs #1 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #2 [[1971 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] | Host = '''#1 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 6| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 14| H3 = 3| H4 = 7 | Date = 1972-01-01 | Location = [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]], [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], [[Florida]] | StartTime = 8:30 pm | TimeZone = EST | Attendance = 73,151 }} {{AFB Game Box End}} In the [[1972 Orange Bowl]], the Huskers battled a #2 team for the second time this season, but [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama]] hardly posed the challenge that the Oklahoma Sooners had been, as Nebraska sent the Crimson Tide to the locker room at the half trailing by an embarrassing 28-0. Alabama managed a feeble third quarter touchdown but failed in the following 2 point conversion and never scored again, while Nebraska responded with 10 more points of their own to close the game and ended the season as [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national champions]] for the second consecutive year. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{See also|1971 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- !
